review.title: Revisiting Chase Termination for Existential Rules and their Extension to Nonmonotonic Negation
review.abstract: Existential rules have been proposed for representing ontological knowledge, specifically in the context of Ontology- Based Data Access. Entailment with existential rules is undecidable. We focus in this paper on conditions that ensure the termination of a breadth-first forward chaining algorithm known as the chase. Several variants of the chase have been proposed. In the first part of this paper, we propose a new tool that allows to extend existing acyclicity conditions ensuring chase termination, while keeping good complexity properties. In the second part, we study the extension to existential rules with nonmonotonic negation under stable model semantics, discuss the relevancy of the chase variants for these rules and further extend acyclicity results obtained in the positive case.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: First, a new tool that makes it possible to unify and extend most existing cyclicity conditions, taking into account good arithmetic properties. Second, a hunting mechanism for non-monotonous existential rules under stable model semantics, as well as the extension of cyclicity conditions taking into account negation. This latter contribution broadens the concept of negative dependence on (Magka, Kro � tzsch and Horrocks 2013) and does not rely on layering (and therefore does not force the existence of a single stable model). This work is continued on the theoretical side by a complexity study of the allocation to the new acyclic classes and by a deeper study of the logical basis for the NME rules, as it remains to relate our core stable sets with an existing first-order semantics for general NME rules.
